learning_outcomes.description: Describe the chemical and physical forces driving biomolecular folding and  interactions, then apply this knowledge to analysis of structures and functions of biomolecules.
Apply your understanding of transcription and translation to develop a molecular cloning strategy.
Interpret and analyse enzymatic function and kinetics.
Predict the impact of altering the components of a metabolic pathway.
Demonstrate theoretical and practical mastery of a range of crucial protein and DNA-related laboratory skills by working in the laboratory and producing a written report about your laboratory work.
Discuss, in an informed manner, the most revolutionary techniques in molecular biology and biochemistry such as restriction enzymes, PCR, GFP, and fusion proteins.
Relate observed biological phenomena to key underlying concepts of biochemistry.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment item consists of two parts:

  1. In-lab worksheets, each related to one of the eight (8) laboratory sessions (Pass/Fail). These will be released to you prior to the lab sessions and you will then complete these in the lab sessions. A pass mark will be awarded for a worksheet by showing your tutor a genuine attempt at the tasks BEFORE leaving the lab session. You will be required to gain a pass mark for ≥75% of the worksheets. These worksheets are formative and will aid you in learning the key concepts that will be tested in the in-class quiz. Additional self-test questions will be available on Blackboard.
  2. In-person, in-class quiz (17.5%). You will complete an in-class quiz that relates to an experimental scenario that will be released to you early in semester. You will be asked questions about the approach used in the scenario, the appropriate analysis of data generated in the scenario, and the conclusions that can be reached. The quizzes will be held in Week 12 and will be timetabled to match your timetabled laboratory session.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Practical absences (complete details in Blackboard)

You must complete 100% of the laboratory component of this course (Assessment Hurdles - under Additional Course Grading Information).

If you cannot complete your timetabled practical session because of circumstances beyond your control (e.g., illness), you must submit an online practical absence request through the Practical Absences link in Blackboard and attach supporting documentation that covers the date of the missed practical. There are limits to the number of applications you may submit (please see Blackboard for details).

Applications must be received within 24 hours of your practical session.

assessments.task_description:
In this assessment you will submit report that includes analysis of data you have collected in the laboratory practicals and figures suitable for publication in a scientific journal that show these data.

A template document will be provided for the report.

Your report must include:

  • an introduction that describes the biological and experimental context of what you did in the lab. This section must be fully referenced.
  • the curated data (e.g., identification and removal (if appropriate) of outliers, determination of means and standard deviations of repeated measures etc.)
  • high quality figures that shows the standard curve(s) accompanied by a figure legend
  • calculation of any unknown values using the standard curve(s)
  • a discussion section that assesses the experimental outcomes with reference to the aims of the work. This section should also address and discuss the quality and reliability of the data, and the limitations of the experimental approaches used. This section must be fully referenced.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
